In Julia, Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

Here is the solution to your problem using Julia programming language:

```julia
using DataFrames, Dates

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map(x -> year(x)*100 + month(x), df.dt)
    return df
end
```

This function takes a DataFrame as input and adds a new column `ym` to it, where each value in the new column is an integer representing the year and month of the corresponding date in the `dt` column. 

The `map` function applies a function (in this case, extracting the year and month from a DateTime) to every element in the `dt` column. The `year` and `month` functions are part of the Dates module in Julia which provides functions for dealing with dates and times.
